meta.dc:rights: the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: To provide for the regulation and control of ports and of vessels in Hong Kong or in the waters of Hong Kong, the regulation and control of repairs and breaking up of vessels, cargo handling on vessels and pollution caused by vessels in the waters of Hong Kong, the regulation for and control of construction or reclamation works in which vessels are used and for other matters affecting vessels, navigation and the safety of vessels at sea (whether within or beyond the waters of Hong Kong).

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title
section.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Shipping and Port Control Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director and any public officer of the Marine Department of or above the rank of Marine Inspector Class II; (Amended 46 of 1981 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any police officer of or above the rank of Sergeant; and (Amended 60 of 1979 s. 2)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any public officer authorized in writing in this behalf by the Director;

section.def: cargo (貨物) means any goods, container, pallet, material and solid ballast, ships’ stores, provisions and equipment, mail and passengers’ baggage, carried, or intended to be carried, in or on a vessel; (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the loading of cargo on, or the unloading of cargo from, a vessel;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the transfer of cargo within a vessel; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the hoisting, lowering, moving and handling of cargo or any other thing in any manner, on or from a vessel;

section.def: collision regulations (碰撞規例) means the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Signals of Distress and Prevention of Collisions) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. N); (Added 57 of 1990 s. 3)

def.name: Crane
def.leadIn: crane (起重機) means any appliance equipped with mechanical means of hoisting and lowering a load and for transporting the load while suspended; and also all chains, ropes, swivels, or other tackle (down to and including the hook), used in the operation of the appliance; but does not include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a hoist block running on a fixed rail or wire;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a stacker or conveyer whereby a load is moved by means of a belt or platform; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an earth or mineral moving or excavating appliance not fitted with a grab; (Added 24 of 2005 s. 40)

def.name: DeadShip
def.leadIn: dead ship (廢船) means any ship exceeding 50 metres in length, other than a laid-up vessel, which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is, for any reason, unable to proceed under its own power;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is, for any reason, unable to manoeuvre with its own steering gear;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is, for any reason, unable to work its own anchors; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: has any part of the hull structure removed, or under repair, which may affect the water-tight integrity of the ship;

section.def: Director (處長) means the Director of Marine;

def.name: Junk
def.leadIn: junk (中式帆船) includes any vessel—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of Chinese or other Asiatic build, construction or rig;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of Chinese or other Asiatic build and construction but of European rig; or (Amended L.N. 386 of 1993)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: of European build and construction, but of Chinese or other Asiatic rig,

def.continued: whether such vessel is of a sea-going type or not and whether mechanically propelled or not;

section.def: lifting appliance (起重裝置) means a crane, winch, hoist, derrick boom, sheer legs, excavator, pile driver, pile extractor, fork lift truck or other self-propelled machine, and any other description of lifting appliance, derrick and mast bands, goose-necks, eyebolts, and all other permanent attachments to a derrick, mast or deck, used on a vessel for the purposes of hoisting or lowering in connection with works; (Added 24 of 2005 s. 40)

lifting gear (起重工具) includes a chain, rope sling, canvas sling, net, tray, board, box, bull rope, snotter, can hook or other means of supporting cargo and attachments thereto including a ring, link, hook, plate, clamp, shackle, swivel, eyebolt, bridle, beam, spreader, rope and wire, used on a vessel in connection with works; (Added 24 of 2005 s. 40)

local vessel (本地船隻) means a local vessel within the meaning of the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) Ordinance (Cap. 548) except a local vessel referred to in section 3(4) of that Ordinance; (Added 43 of 1999 s. 91)

marine construction (海上建造工程) means any construction or reclamation works, including dredging, drilling, pipe laying, buoy laying, cable laying and caisson construction, in which vessels are used; (Added 24 of 2005 s. 40)
master (船長), in relation to a vessel, means the person (except a pilot) having for the time being command or charge of the vessel; (Amended 43 of 1999 s. 91)
material (物料) includes construction material, waste material and debris; (Added 70 of 1999 s. 3)

mooring (繫泊設備) includes a mooring dolphin or post, buoy, pontoon, floating pier or other floating structure used for the mooring of vessels or to assist in the embarkation or disembarkation to or from vessels;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to a vessel, means—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the person or persons registered as the owner of the vessel, or in the absence of registration, the person or persons owning the vessel, except that in relation to a vessel owned by a State which is operated by a person registered as the vessel’s operator, it means the person registered as its operator; or (Amended 43 of 1999 s. 91)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a demise charterer of the vessel; and

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the consignor, consignee or shipper of the cargo; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the agent of the owner of the cargo;

def.name: PersonInChargeOfWorks
def.leadIn: person in charge of works (工程負責人) means—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a principal contractor or sub-contractor, if any, who contracts to carry out, or who carries out, any works; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other person having for the time being the command or charge of any works being carried out on, to or by means of a vessel; (Added 24 of 2005 s. 40)

section.def: pilot (領港員) means the person who is a pilot within the meaning of the Pilotage Ordinance (Cap. 84);

def.name: PlaceOnLand
def.leadIn: place on land (陸上地方) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any premises, building or vehicle on land;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any building, structure or object erected or placed on the bed or shore of the sea; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: anything afloat (other than a vessel) if it is anchored or attached to the bed or shore of the sea;

section.def: port facility (港口設施) means any aid to navigation, mooring or signal station;

principal contractor (總承判商) means a person who enters into a contract directly with the owner or master of, or other person having control over, a vessel to carry out any works; (Added 24 of 2005 s. 40)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any vessel, means any repairs, alterations or maintenance works on or to the vessel carried out by any person other than a member of the crew or the master of the vessel or that involve or are likely to involve the safety of any person other than a member of the crew or the master of the vessel; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any vessel carrying dangerous goods, means any repairs, alterations or maintenance works on or to the vessel capable of providing an ignition source, including those that involve welding, burning or the use of blow lamps, braziers or other devices using combustible materials; (Added 24 of 2005 s. 40)

def.name: RiverTradeLimits
def.leadIn: river trade limits (內河航限) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the waters in the vicinity of Hong Kong within the following boundaries—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to the East, meridian 114° 30’ East;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to the South, parallel 22° 09’ North; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: to the West, meridian 113° 31’ East; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all inland waterways in the Guangdong Province and Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region to which access can be obtained by water from the area defined in paragraph (a); (Amended L.N. 80 of 2012)

section.def: ship (船、船舶) means any vessel used in navigation other than a local vessel or a junk; (Amended 43 of 1999 s. 91)
signal station (信號站) means a signal station so specified by regulations made under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any person who enters into a contract, express or implied, with a principal contractor to perform all or any part of the works which the principal contractor has contracted to perform; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person who enters into a contract, express or implied, to perform all or any part of the works which a sub-contractor within the meaning of paragraph (a) has contracted to perform; (Added 24 of 2005 s. 40)

section.def: tons (噸) and tonnage (噸位) mean tons and tonnage as calculated according to the Merchant Shipping (Registration) (Tonnage) Regulations (Cap. 415 sub. leg. C); (Amended 64 of 1999 s. 3)

use of signals of distress regulations (《使用遇險訊號規例》) means the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Use of Signals of Distress) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. O); (Added 57 of 1990 s. 3. Amended 70 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any ship, junk, boat, dynamically supported craft, seaplane, or any other description of vessel used in navigation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other description of vessel in Hong Kong or in the waters of Hong Kong not used in navigation or not constructed or adapted for use in navigation; (Amended 46 of 1981 s. 3)

section.def: waters of Hong Kong (香港水域) means waters of Hong Kong within the meaning of section 3 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1); (Replaced 26 of 1998 s. 44. Amended 24 of 2005 s. 40)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: repairs to a vessel;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the breaking up of a vessel;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: cargo handling; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: marine construction. (Added 24 of 2005 s. 40)

subsection.content: This Ordinance shall, except where otherwise specially provided, apply to all vessels (except local vessels) in Hong Kong or in the waters of Hong Kong, including vessels for the time being used by the Hong Kong Government and all warships and ships for the time being used by the Chinese People’s Liberation Army, the Central People’s Government or the Government of any State. (Amended 46 of 1981 s. 4; 43 of 1999 s. 91; 2 of 2012 s. 3)
Nothing in this Ordinance shall derogate from the provisions of any other law.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Installation of Government port facilities
section.content: The Director may lay, place, erect and maintain under his control in the waters of Hong Kong such port facilities as he thinks fit.

subsection.content: Subject to any other provision of this Ordinance, no person shall use a port facility otherwise than for the purpose for which it is provided.
Any person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

section.name: s6
section.heading: Restriction on installation of private port facilities, etc.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), except with the written permission of the Director, no person shall lay, place, erect or maintain a port facility or any floating or other structure in the waters of Hong Kong.

The Director may, by notice in the Gazette, specify any area of the waters of Hong Kong in which any floating or other structure specified in the notice may be laid, placed, erected or maintained without the permission of the Director.
Any person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

Without prejudice to the liability for an offence under subsection (3), the Director may give such directions as he thinks fit for the removal, moving or modification of a port facility or any floating or other structure laid, placed, erected or maintained in contravention of subsection (1).

section.name: s7
section.heading: Damage, etc., to aids to navigation

subsection.leadIn: Any person who wilfully or negligently—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: removes, alters, damages, destroys, or interferes with, any aid to navigation or mooring; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: makes fast to any aid to navigation,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2.

subsection.content: If an offence under subsection (1) is committed by a person on or in respect of a vessel, then, in addition to that person, the owner and the master of the vessel commit an offence and each of them is liable to a fine at level 2.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Liability for damage to port facilities, etc.

subsection.content: Where any damage is caused by a vessel to any port facility, pier, breakwater or other property owned by the Government, the owner and the master of the vessel shall, without prejudice to the liability for an offence under this Ordinance, be jointly and severally liable for any loss arising out of the damage to the extent that such loss is attributable to any fault on the part of the vessel of to any wilful or negligent act of any person on the vessel.
Such loss may be recovered by the Director as a civil debt.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Power to require removal of unauthorized lights and signs
section.leadIn: The Director may direct an owner or his agent or the master of any vessel, or any person who appears to him to be the owner or occupier of a place on land, at or from which there is exhibited a light or illuminated sign which, in the opinion of the Director—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: obscures, restricts or interferes with, or is likely to obscure, restrict or interfere with, the functions or use of any signal station or aid to navigation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is likely to be mistaken for a light or signal proceeding from any signal station or aid to navigation; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any way interferes with, or is likely to interfere with, the safe navigation of vessels in the waters of Hong Kong,

section.continued: to remove the light or illuminated sign or to extinguish or screen it in the manner specified in the direction.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Application of collision regulations and use of signals of distress regulations

subsection.leadIn: Subject to any special provision in or under this Ordinance, the collision regulations and the use of signals of distress regulations shall apply—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to all vessels (not being ships to which the regulations apply pursuant to the provisions of the Merchant Shipping (Safety) Ordinance (Cap. 369)) while they are within the waters of Hong Kong, (Amended 43 of 1999 s. 91)

subsection.continued: and shall, for the purpose of their application by virtue of this section, be read and construed as if references to ships were references to vessels. (Amended 43 of 1999 s. 91)

subsection.content: For the purpose of subsection (1) the collision regulations and the use of signals of distress regulations shall each be deemed to have been made under section 80 and may be amended thereunder.

If any of the collision regulations is contravened by a vessel, the owner of the vessel, the master and any person for the time being responsible for the conduct of the vessel shall each be guilty of an offence and liable to a fine at level 4. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)
It shall be a defence to a charge under subsection (3) for the person charged to prove that he took all reasonable precautions to prevent the contravention to which the charge relates.

subsection.leadIn: If the master of a vessel uses or displays or causes or permits any person under his authority to use or display—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any signal prescribed by the collision regulations except in the circumstances and for the purposes prescribed by the use of signals of distress regulations; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any private signal, whether registered or not, which is liable to be mistaken for any signal prescribed by the collision regulations,

subsection.continued: he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4 and shall further be liable to pay compensation for any labour undertaken, risk incurred or loss sustained in consequence of the signal having been supposed to be a signal of distress; and that compensation may, without prejudice to any other remedy, be recovered in the same manner as salvage. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

subsection.content: Notwithstanding anything in the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227) an information or complaint relating to an offence under this section which has been committed outside Hong Kong may be laid or made at any time within 2 years from the commission of the offence.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Application
section.leadIn: Sections 11A and 11B shall apply in relation to all vessels whether within or outside the waters of Hong Kong except for—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any warship or other ship for the time being used by the Chinese People’s Liberation Army or the Central People’s Government other than for commercial purposes. (Amended 2 of 2012 s. 3)

section.name: s11A
section.heading: Notification prior to arrival of vessels
section.content: Subject to any provision in or pursuant to this Ordinance, where a vessel is expected to arrive in the waters of Hong Kong, the owner or the master of the vessel shall notify the Director of such expected arrival not less than 24 hours before the arrival of the vessel, or, if that is not practicable, as early as practicable before the arrival of the vessel.

section.name: s11B
section.heading: Refusal of permission to enter, leave, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding any other provision in this Ordinance, the Director may, if he is satisfied that there is reason for doing so, give directions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refusing permission for a vessel or class, type or description of vessel to enter or leave the waters of Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: requiring the removal of a vessel or class, type or description of vessel from the waters of Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of subsection (1) and without prejudice to any of the Director’s powers under this Ordinance, the Director may give directions prohibiting the entry of a vessel into, or requiring the removal of a vessel from, the waters of Hong Kong if in his opinion the condition of that vessel or the nature or condition of anything it contains is such that its presence in the waters of Hong Kong may involve—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: grave and imminent danger to the safety of any person or property; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: grave and imminent risk that the vessel may, by sinking, foundering or otherwise, prevent or seriously prejudice the use of any part of the waters of Hong Kong by other vessels.

subsection.content: Any directions under subsection (1) or (2) may be given as respects the vessel in question to the owner or the master of the vessel.
At any time any directions under subsection (1) or (2) are given to any person, the Director shall inform that person of the grounds for giving such directions.

If any directions of the Director under subsection (2) were not reasonably necessary to prevent or reduce the danger or risk provided therein, a person incurring expense or suffering damage as a result of any action taken in compliance with the Director’s directions shall be entitled to claim and recover compensation from the Government.

Nothing in this section shall affect the exercise by the Director of any of the powers conferred on him by section 6 of the Merchant Shipping (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Ordinance (Cap. 413). (Amended 64 of 1999 s. 3)

If without reasonable excuse section 11A is contravened, the owner and the master of the vessel each commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: If a vessel which is refused permission under section 11B(1)(a) or which is prohibited under section 11B(2) to enter the waters of Hong Kong so enters without reasonable excuse, the owner and the master of the vessel each commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $250,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years and to an additional fine of $25,000 for each day during which the vessel in question remains in the waters of Hong Kong without reasonable excuse after so entering.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: If a vessel which is refused permission under section 11B(1)(a) to leave the waters of Hong Kong so leaves without reasonable excuse, the owner and the master of the vessel each commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $250,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: If without reasonable excuse a direction under section 11B(1)(b) or (2) for the removal of a vessel from the waters of Hong Kong is not complied with, the owner and the master of the vessel each commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $250,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years and to an additional fine of $25,000 for each day during which the vessel in question remains in the waters of Hong Kong without reasonable excuse.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a vessel is refused permission to leave the waters of Hong Kong under section 11B; or (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 5)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is provided in this Ordinance that under specified conditions a vessel shall not leave any port or the waters of Hong Kong,

subsection.continued: the Director may take such steps as are necessary to detain the vessel in such port or waters.

subsection.leadIn: If the Director incurs any cost in detaining a vessel under subsection (1), he may recover the cost—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as a civil debt from the owner or master of the vessel; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: under section 55 as if the cost represented port dues payable in respect of the vessel.

subsection.content: Where any vessel not registered in Hong Kong is detained under subsection (1), notice thereof shall be given to the consular officer for the State to which the vessel belongs, and if there is no such consular officer to the master of the vessel, and such notice shall specify the grounds on which the vessel has been detained. (Amended 23 of 1998 s. 2)

section.name: s13
section.heading: Penalty for taking detained vessel to sea

subsection.content: If a vessel which is detained under section 12 proceeds to sea the master, and the owner or his agent if he is party or privy to such action, commit an offence and each of them is liable to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 2 years. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: Where a vessel proceeds to sea in contravention of subsection (1) whilst having on board a public officer who is acting in the execution of his duty—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the master and the owner or his agent, in addition to committing an offence under subsection (1), commit an offence under this subsection and each of them is liable to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months, and to an additional fine of $1,000 for each day during the period from the date on which the vessel proceeded to sea until the date on which the officer is returned to Hong Kong or, if he does not return directly to Hong Kong, would have returned if he had travelled by the quickest practicable route; and (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the master and the owner and his agent shall be jointly and severally liable to pay all expenses incidental to the taking of the officer to sea and to securing his return to Hong Kong, and all such expenses may be recovered in the same manner as a fine.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Director to be allowed to board

subsection.content: When a ship arrives within the waters of Hong Kong, the master of the ship shall allow and assist the Director to board the ship as soon as he comes alongside the ship and shall give to the Director such information as he may be required to give under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Any master or officer of a ship who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to allow, or fails to assist, the Director to board the ship; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: delays or impedes the Director from boarding the ship,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

section.name: s15
section.heading: Port clearance to be obtained before departure

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), no vessel shall proceed to sea unless there is in relation to the vessel a valid port clearance in writing obtained in the prescribed manner.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) shall not apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to any warship or other ship for the time being used by the Chinese People’s Liberation Army, the Central People’s Government or the Government of any State for other than commercial purposes; (Amended 2 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to any vessel for the time being used by the Hong Kong Government;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to any vessel of a class that is exempted by the Director by notice in the Gazette from the operation of this section;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to any vessel that is obliged to leave any port or the waters of Hong Kong due to weather conditions, or other circumstances beyond the control of its master, in the interests of safety of the vessel, its cargo, crew or passengers.

subsection.content: If subsection (1) is contravened, the master commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

section.name: s16
section.heading: Power to give directions
section.leadIn: The Director may give to an owner or his agent or to a master of, or other person who appears to the Director to be in control over, a vessel such directions as he thinks fit in any particular case—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for controlling the vessel when entering or leaving the waters of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for controlling the navigation and movement of the vessel in the waters of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: as to the place and manner in which the vessel shall be berthed, moored, anchored or secured;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: for the removal of the vessel from any berth, mooring or anchorage to another berth, mooring or anchorage;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: prohibiting the berthing, mooring or anchoring of the vessel in any particular place;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: for ensuring the safety of, or preventing the outbreak of fire on, the vessel in the waters of Hong Kong. (Amended 46 of 1981 s. 5)

subsection.content: Without prejudice to the generality of section 16, the Director may, by notice in the Gazette, give to an owner or his agent or to a master of, or other person who appears to the Director to be in control over, any vessel belonging to a class, type or description of vessel specified in the notice such directions as he thinks fit in respect of any matter in relation to which the Director may give directions under that section.

A notice under subsection (1) which has not been repealed, or which has not expired, on or before the effluxion of the period of 6 months immediately following the day on which it is published in the Gazette shall expire on the day immediately following that period.

subsection.leadIn: It is hereby declared that a notice under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is subsidiary legislation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be in the same terms as another notice under that subsection where that first-mentioned notice is to come into operation upon or after the expiration of that second-mentioned notice.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to the generality of section 61(5) or (6), sections 61(1), (2), (3) and (4) and 66 shall not apply to a direction given in a notice under subsection (1).

Where the Director reasonably believes that it is necessary in the interests of safety to close any area of the waters of Hong Kong to all vessels, or to any vessel belonging to any class, type or description of vessel, he may, by notice in the Gazette, close that area to such vessels or vessel, as the case may be.

A notice under subsection (1) which has not been repealed, or which has not expired, on or before the effluxion of the period of 6 months immediately following the day on which it is published in the Gazette shall expire on the day immediately following that period.

subsection.leadIn: It is hereby declared that a notice under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is subsidiary legislation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be in the same terms as another notice under that subsection where that first-mentioned notice is to come into operation upon or after the expiration of that second-mentioned notice;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: shall not apply to any vessel which is being used for any fire services, ambulance, police, customs and excise or Marine Department purpose if compliance with the notice is likely to hinder the use of that vessel for that purpose.

subsection.content: If without reasonable excuse a vessel the subject of a notice under subsection (1) enters an area of the waters of Hong Kong the subject of that notice, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

Subject to subsection (2), no ship or junk shall, except with the permission of the Director, anchor at any place in the waters of Hong Kong other than in a port or at a specified anchorage specified in Schedule 3 to the Pilotage Ordinance (Cap. 84). (Amended 29 of 1985 s. 8; 18 of 2014 s. 162)

Subsection (1) shall not apply where a ship or junk anchors at any place in the waters of Hong Kong, other than in a place in which anchoring is expressly restricted or prohibited under this Ordinance, because of stress of weather or other sufficient cause.
If subsection (1) is contravened, the master commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)
No dead ship shall, except with the permission of the Director, enter, or be brought into, the waters of Hong Kong.
Subject to subsection (4), no dead ship shall, except with the written permission of the Director, be berthed, moored or anchored at any place in the waters of Hong Kong.

Subject to subsection (4), no owner, agent or master of a ship which is within the waters of Hong Kong shall, except with the written permission of the Director, carry out, or cause to be carried out, any maintenance or repair work on the ship which will result in the ship becoming a dead ship.
Subsections (2) and (3) do not apply to a dead ship which is drydocked or within the precincts of, or berthed or moored alongside, a dockyard.

Without prejudice to section 64(5), a permission granted under this section may be withdrawn or cancelled by the Director at any time if the dead ship becomes, or is likely to become, a danger to life, other vessels, port facilities or other property.

If without reasonable excuse subsection (1), (2) or (3) is contravened, the owner or his agent and the master commit an offence and each of them is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)
Subject to subsection (2), no laid-up vessel shall, except with the written permission of the Director, be berthed, moored or anchored at any place in the waters of Hong Kong.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a laid-up vessel which is drydocked or within the precincts of, or berthed or moored alongside, a dockyard.

If without reasonable excuse subsection (1) is contravened, the owner or his agent and the master commit an offence and each of them is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: Where a vessel—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is on fire;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has suffered damage by fire, explosion or collision; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is disabled, stranded or out of control because of damage, bad weather or mechanical failure,

subsection.continued: the Director may, if he has reasonable grounds to believe that any of the circumstances specified in subsection (2) prevail, direct the owner or master of the vessel— (Amended L.N. 386 of 1993)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: to beach the vessel;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: to take the vessel outside the limits of a port; or

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: to take such other action as the Director thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: The circumstances for the purposes of subsection (1) are that the vessel—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is, or is likely to become, a danger to life, other vessels, aircraft or navigation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is causing, or is likely to cause, pollution of the waters of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is causing, or is likely to cause, damage to port facilities or other property.

subsection.content: If without reasonable excuse any direction given under subsection (1) is not complied with, the owner or master to whom the direction is given commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 1 year. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

section.name: s21
section.heading: Removal, etc. of stranded, abandoned or sunken vessel

subsection.content: The Director may give to an owner or master of, or other person who claims or appears to the Director to exercise control over, a vessel which is stranded, abandoned or sunk in the waters of Hong Kong such directions as he thinks fit in respect of the removal, movement, anchoring, mooring, securing, raising or destruction of the vessel. (Amended L.N. 307 of 1998)

If without reasonable excuse any direction given under subsection (1) is not complied with, the person to whom the direction is given commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 1 year. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: The Director may seize and detain a vessel referred to in subsection (1) together with any cargo and other things on board if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a direction given under subsection (1) is not complied with;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after reasonable inquiry he is unable to ascertain the ownership of the vessel or to trace the owner or master of the vessel; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no person claims or appears to the Director to exercise control over the vessel.

subsection.content: For the purposes of seizing a vessel, cargo or other things under subsection (3), the Director may take, or cause to be taken, any action that is necessary including the employment of pilots and the use of tugs and equipment to remove, move, anchor, moor, secure or raise the vessel, cargo and other things.

subsection.leadIn: The Director shall publish in the Gazette and in one English language and one Chinese language newspaper circulating in Hong Kong a notice of a seizure effected under subsection (3) and the notice shall specify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the names (if known to the Director) of the persons whom the Director believes to be the owner and the master of the vessel;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: a description of the vessel and the place at which it was seized;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a description of the cargo or other things on board; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a reasonable period within which and the place at which a claim shall be submitted to the Director for the release of the vessel, cargo or other things on board.

subsection.content: If a valid claim to a vessel, cargo or other things seized under subsection (3) is submitted at any time before a notice is published under subsection (5) or within the period specified in a notice published under that subsection, the Director shall, on payment to him of all expenses involved in the seizure and custody of the vessel, cargo or other things, as the case may be, release the vessel, cargo or other things to the claimant.

If the release of a vessel, cargo or other things is not obtained in pursuance of subsection (6), the Director may sell, or otherwise dispose of in such manner as he thinks fit, the vessel, cargo or other things, as the case may be, and in the case of sale the proceeds, after deducting all expenses payable under subsection (6) and any reasonable expense incurred in the sale, shall be paid to the person making a valid claim thereto within 1 year after the date of sale or forfeited to the Government if not claimed within that period. (Amended 64 of 1999 s. 3; E.R. 3 of 2021)

section.name: s22
section.heading: Notice of change of ownership of stranded, abandoned or sunken vessels

subsection.content: Where the owner of a vessel which is stranded, abandoned or sunk in the waters of Hong Kong sells the vessel, or otherwise parts with the ownership of the vessel, he shall forthwith notify the Director in writing of the name and address of the new owner of the vessel.
Any owner who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

section.name: s23
section.heading: Vessels not registered in Hong Kong, etc.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a vessel not registered in Hong Kong is stranded, abandoned or sunk in the waters of Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a vessel not registered in Hong Kong which is stranded, abandoned or sunk near the coast of Hong Kong, or any part of such vessel or cargo or other thing belonging thereto, is brought into Hong Kong,

section.continued: and the owner or master of the vessel, or the owner of the cargo or other thing, as the case may be, is not in Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the consular officer of the country to which the vessel, or in the case of cargo or other thing to which its owner, may have belonged; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the consular officer of that country authorized in that behalf by any treaty or arrangement with that country,

section.continued: shall be deemed to be the agent of the owner of the vessel, cargo or other thing so far as relates to its custody and disposal.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: approved code (《守則》) means a code of practice issued under section 44A; (Added 70 of 1999 s. 7)

def.name: MachineryEquipmentOrAppliance
def.leadIn: machinery, equipment or appliance (機械、裝備或裝置), in the case of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: repairs to a vessel, means any machinery, equipment or appliance provided or used for that purpose;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the breaking up of a vessel, means any machinery, equipment or appliance provided or used for that purpose; (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 7)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: cargo handling, means any lifting appliance or lifting gear provided or used for that purpose; and (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 7)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: marine construction, means any machinery, equipment or appliance provided or used for that purpose. (Added 70 of 1999 s. 7. Amended 24 of 2005 s. 41)

subsection.leadIn: This Part shall not apply to repairs to, or the breaking up of, a vessel which is— (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 8)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in a dock other than a floating dock; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: on a slip or mechanical lift.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Appointment of inspectors
section.content: The Director shall appoint such persons as he thinks fit to be inspectors for the purposes of this Part.

subsection.leadIn: The Director and an inspector shall have power—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at any reasonable time (or, in a situation which in the opinion of the Director or an inspector is or may be dangerous, at any time) to board any vessel within the waters of Hong Kong which he has reason to believe it is necessary to board for the purposes of this Part, and for the purpose of boarding any such vessel which is floating alongside any premises at a seawall or pier, to enter such premises;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to take with him such persons as may be necessary to assist him in the exercise of his powers, or performance of his duties, under this Part;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to inspect and examine any vessel on or to which any works are being carried out;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to make such examination and inquiry as may be necessary to ascertain that safe working conditions obtain and that the provisions of this Part are complied with;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to investigate any accident involving any works or injury to any person arising out of or in the course of carrying out any works;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to require the production of any register, certificate or other document required to be kept in pursuance of regulations made under section 80 and to inspect and copy any of them or any entry in them; and (Amended 24 of 2005 s. 42)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: to require the posting of any notice in pursuance of regulations made under section 80 or any notice related to works, machinery, equipment or appliances, or the safety of persons employed in carrying out any works. (Amended 24 of 2005 s. 42)

subsection.content: An owner or master of, or other person having control over, a vessel shall furnish such safe means required by the Director or an inspector as are necessary for the purposes of boarding, inspection, examination, investigation, or otherwise for the exercise of his powers under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse fails to comply with any requirement of the Director or an inspector in pursuance of this section;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse fails to produce any register, certificate or other document which he is required in pursuance of this Part to produce;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse withholds any information as to who is the owner or master of, or person having control over, the vessel, or the owner of any machinery, equipment or appliance provided or used for the carrying out of any works,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 9)

section.name: s40
section.heading: Restriction on carrying out repairs or breaking up of vessels

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (1A) and (2), no owner or master of, or other person having control over, a vessel shall, except with the written permission of the Director, carry out, or cause to be carried out, any repairs to, or break up, the vessel. (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 10)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Subsections (1) does not apply to any vessels of 50 metres or less in length unless the Director gives written notification to the person in charge of works that subsection (1) applies to that vessel. (Added 70 of 1999 s. 10)
The Director may by notice in the Gazette specify any type of repairs to a vessel in respect of which permission under subsection (1) is not required.
Any person who without reasonable excuse contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years. (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 10)

subsection.leadIn: Where a vessel is being repaired or broken up, the person in charge of works shall not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide or use, or cause to be provided or used, any machinery, equipment or appliance that is capable of providing an ignition source; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: carry out, or cause to be carried out, any works that involve welding or burning, the use of blow lamps, braziers or other devices using combustible materials,

subsection.continued: in an atmosphere containing flammable vapours, flammable gases or explosive dusts.

subsection.content: A person in charge of works who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year. (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 11)

section.name: s42
section.heading: Directions regarding repairs or breaking up of vessels

subsection.leadIn: The Director may direct any person who, in the opinion of the Director, is the owner or master of a vessel, or who claims or appears to the Director to exercise control over a vessel, that is to be repaired or broken up or is being repaired or broken up, or who is in charge of the repairs or the breaking up of a vessel—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to remove the vessel to a position or place within the waters of Hong Kong specified by the Director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to comply with such safety requirements as may be specified by the Director generally or in any particular case;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to comply with any other requirements which may be specified by the Director in respect of the manner in which the vessel may be repaired or broken up;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in the case of the breaking up of a vessel, to give security, in cash or otherwise, in such amount as the Director may consider necessary to ensure the effective breaking up and complete removal of the vessel.

subsection.content: Any person who fails to comply with any direction given to him under subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months, and to an additional fine of $2,000 for each day during which such failure to comply continues after notice requiring compliance with the direction has been served by the Director on such person. (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 12)

section.name: s43
section.heading: Prohibition against use of dangerous equipment, etc.

subsection.content: A person in charge of works shall not provide or use, or cause to be provided or used, any machinery, equipment or appliance for the carrying out of the works if the machinery, equipment or appliance is in such a condition or so constructed that it cannot be used without unnecessary risk of accident or bodily injury.

subsection.leadIn: If the Director or an inspector has reasonable grounds to believe that any machinery, equipment or appliance provided or used for the carrying out of any works is in such a condition or so constructed that it cannot be used without unnecessary risk of accident or bodily injury, the Director or inspector may give directions to the person in charge of works—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prohibiting the use of the machinery, equipment or appliance, or if it is capable of repair or alteration, prohibiting its use until it is repaired or altered as specified in the direction; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: requiring him to take such other steps as may be specified in the directions for remedying the unnecessary risk of accident or bodily injury.

subsection.leadIn: A person in charge of works who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year; (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to comply with any direction given to him under subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months, and to an additional fine of $2,000 for each day during which such failure to comply continues after notice requiring compliance with the direction has been served by the Director or an inspector on such person. (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 13)

section.name: s44
section.heading: Prohibition against carrying out works in dangerous conditions

subsection.content: A person in charge of works shall not carry out, or cause to be carried out, any works in a condition or manner that does not provide adequately against unnecessary risk of accident or bodily injury.

If the Director or an inspector has reasonable grounds to believe that any works are being carried out in a condition or manner that does not provide adequately against unnecessary risk of accident or bodily injury, the Director or inspector may give directions to the person in charge of the works requiring him to take such steps as may be specified in the directions for remedying the unnecessary risk of accident or bodily injury.

subsection.leadIn: A person in charge of works who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year; (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to comply with any direction given to him under subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months, and to an additional fine of $2,000 for each day during which such failure to comply continues after notice requiring compliance with the direction has been served by the Director or an inspector on such person. (Amended 70 of 1999 s. 14)

subsection.content: For the purpose of providing practical guidance in respect of any one or more of the requirements of this Part or of regulations made under this Ordinance, the Director may issue such codes of practice (whether prepared by the Director or not) as the Director considers appropriate.
The Director may amend or revoke a code of practice issued by him under subsection (1).

Where the Director exercises a power under subsection (1) or (2), he shall as soon as may be reasonably practicable publish notice thereof in the Gazette and the notice shall be in such form as the Director considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: A failure by any person to observe a provision of an approved code shall not of itself cause him to incur any criminal liability, but where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in any criminal proceedings the defendant is alleged to have committed an offence either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by reason of a contravention of or a failure to comply with, whether by act or omission, this Ordinance or regulations under this Ordinance; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: by reason of a failure to discharge or perform a duty imposed by this Ordinance or such regulations; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the matter to which the alleged contravention or failure relates is one to which, in the opinion of the court, an approved code relates,

subsection.continued: then subsection (5) shall apply as regards to the proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: In any criminal proceedings to which this subsection applies, the following, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: compliance with a provision of an approved code found by the court to be relevant to a matter to which a contravention or failure alleged in the proceedings relates;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a contravention of or failure to comply with, whether by act or omission, any such provision so found,

subsection.continued: may be relied on by any party to the proceedings as tending to establish or to negative any liability which is in question in the proceedings.

subsection.content: In any criminal proceedings, and document which purports to be a copy of a particular approved code shall, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, be regarded by the court as being a true copy of that code.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Interpretation
section.def: mixture containing oil (含油混合物) means any mixture of oil with water or with any other substance, and any waste consisting of or arising from oil;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a place on land, if it has no occupier, means the owner thereof; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a vehicle, means the person in charge of the vehicle and not the occupier of the land on which the vehicle stands;

section.def: oil (油) means oil of any description, spirit produced from oil of any description and coal tar.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Discharge of oil into the waters of Hong Kong

subsection.leadIn: If any oil or mixture containing oil is discharged into the waters of Hong Kong, then the following commit an offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person by whom the oil or mixture containing oil is so discharged or caused to be discharged; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: whether or not the person referred to in paragraph (a) has been charged with an offence—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: if the discharge is from a vessel, the owner and the master of the vessel, unless the owner or master, as the case may be, proves that the discharge took place and was caused as mentioned in subparagraph (ii);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the discharge is from a vessel but takes place in the course of a transfer of oil to or from another vessel or a place on land and is caused by the act or omission of any person in charge of any apparatus in that other vessel or that place, the owner and the master of that other vessel or, as the case may be, the occupier of that place;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if the discharge is from a place on land, the occupier of that place, unless he proves that the discharge was caused by the act of a person who is in that place without the permission (express or implied) of the occupier;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: if the discharge takes place otherwise than as mentioned in subparagraph (i), (ii) or (iii) and is the result of any operations for the exploration of the seabed and subsoil or the exploration of their natural resources, the person carrying on the operations.

subsection.content: Reference in subsection (1) to the discharge of oil or mixture containing oil, or to its being discharged, from a vessel or place on land includes a reference to the escape of the oil or mixture containing oil, or (as the case may be) to its escaping, from that vessel or place on land. [cf. 1971 c. 60 s. 29(3) U.K.]
Any person who commits an offence under this section is liable to a fine of $200,000.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is charged with an offence under section 46 as the owner or master of a vessel it shall be a defence to prove that the oil or mixture containing oil was discharged for the purpose of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: securing the safety of the vessel;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: preventing damage to the vessel or its cargo; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: saving life,

subsection.continued: unless the court is satisfied that the discharge of the oil or mixture containing oil was not necessary for that purpose or was not a reasonable step to take in the circumstances.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is charged as mentioned in subsection (1) it shall also be a defence to prove—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the oil or mixture containing oil escaped in consequence of damage to the vessel and that as soon as practicable after the damage occurred all reasonable steps were taken for preventing, or (if it could not be prevented) for stopping or reducing, the escape of the oil or mixture containing oil; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the oil or mixture containing oil escaped by reason of leakage, that neither the leakage nor any delay in discovering it was due to want of reasonable care, and that as soon as practicable after the escape was discovered all reasonable steps were taken for stopping or reducing it.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Duty to report discharge of oil into Hong Kong waters

subsection.leadIn: If any oil or mixture containing oil—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is discharged from a vessel into the waters of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is found to be escaping or to have escaped from a vessel into any such waters; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is found to be escaping or to have escaped into any such waters from a place on land,

subsection.continued: the owner or master of the vessel, or the occupier of the place on land, as the case may be, shall forthwith report the occurrence to the Director.

subsection.content: A report made under subsection (1) by the owner or master of the vessel shall state whether the occurrence falls within paragraph (a) or (b) of that subsection.
Any person who fails to make a report as required by this section commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

section.name: s48A
section.heading: Discharges under the Water Pollution Control Ordinance
section.content: No offence under section 46 is committed by, and no obligation arises under section 48 on the part of, any person who makes a discharge or deposit of oil or a mixture containing oil under and in accordance with a licence for the purposes of the Water Pollution Control Ordinance (Cap. 358).
section.sourceNote: (Added 41 of 1980 s. 50. Amended 42 of 1985 s. 6; 67 of 1990 s. 23)

section.name: s49
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: dark smoke (黑煙) means smoke which would appear to be as dark as, or darker than, shade 2 on a specified chart; (Added 13 of 2014 s. 3)
smoke (煙霧) includes soot, ash, grit and gritty particles emitted in smoke or steam; (Amended 13 of 2014 s. 3)

specified chart (指明圖表) means a shade chart of the type known on the commencement date* of the Shipping Legislation (Control of Smoke Emission) (Amendment) Ordinance 2014 (13 of 2014) as a Ringelmann Chart and includes a Micro-Ringelmann Chart. (Added 13 of 2014 s. 3)

section.name: s50
section.heading: Emission of dark smoke from vessels

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), no vessel in the waters of Hong Kong shall emit dark smoke for 3 minutes or more continuously at any one time.
Subsection (1) shall not apply to the emission of dark smoke in circumstances affecting the safety of life or of the vessel.
If subsection (1) is contravened, the owner and master of the vessel and the owner’s agent each commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: Each person who commits an offence under subsection (3) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: if the person has previously committed the offence in relation to the vessel, to a fine at level 5. (Added 13 of 2014 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may make regulations for all or any of the following purposes— (Amended 64 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specifying periods during which emission of smoke from vessels may be permitted in any class of case and subject to limitations;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the adoption of precautions against the emission of smoke from vessels;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: generally for effectively controlling the emission of smoke from vessels.

subsection.content: Any regulations made under this section may provide that a contravention of specified provisions thereof is an offence and may prescribe penalties therefor not exceeding a fine at level 2. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

Subject to subsection (2), the owner, his agent and the master of every vessel which enters any port or other part of the waters of Hong Kong, or which uses any port facility, shall be jointly and severally liable to pay in respect of the vessel such port dues as may be prescribed.

Subsection (1) shall not apply to any vessel for the time being used by the Hong Kong Government or to any warship or ship for the time being used by the Chinese People’s Liberation Army, the Central People’s Government or the Government of any State for other than commercial purposes. (Amended 2 of 2012 s. 3)

The Director, Deputy Director of Marine or an Assistant Director of Marine may refund or waive the payment of, in whole or in part, any port dues in respect of any vessel, or class, type or description of vessel, used for other than commercial purposes.
Port dues shall be paid to the Director on demand made by him.
The Director may require the payment of port dues in advance in the case of any specified vessel, or specified class, type or description of vessel.
The Director may in any particular case or class of case permit the port dues to be paid in arrear, subject to such conditions as to security or time for payment as he thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: If any port dues are not paid on demand—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where payment is required to be made in advance under section 53(2), the Director may refuse permission for the vessel to enter the waters of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where payment is required to be made before a vessel leaves the waters of Hong Kong, the Director may refuse permission for the vessel to leave the waters of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the port dues payable may be recovered as a civil debt from the owner, his agent and the master of the vessel either jointly or severally.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to subsection (1)(c), a master of a vessel who leaves any port or other part of the waters of Hong Kong without paying any port dues which he is required by the Director to pay commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

Notwithstanding anything in the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227), proceedings in respect of an offence under this section may be brought at any time within 2 years next after the commission of the offence.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Recovery of port dues by seizure

subsection.content: If the owner or his agent or the master of a vessel fails on demand to pay any port dues payable in respect of the vessel, the Director may, without prejudice to section 54, board the vessel and seize the goods, tackle, or any thing belonging to, or on board, the vessel, and detain such goods, tackle or thing until the port dues are paid.

If payment of the port dues is not made within the 3 days following the seizure, the Director may, at any time during the continuance of the non-payment, cause the goods, tackle or thing seized to be appraised by 2 persons (other than public officers) appointed for that purpose by the Director, and thereupon sell the same and apply the proceeds in payment of the port dues and all reasonable expenses incurred by him under this section, and pay the balance (if any) on demand to the owner or master of the vessel.

section.name: s55A
section.heading: Interpretation of Part VIIIA
section.def: e-document database (電子文件資料庫) means an electronic database that is maintained or managed by or for the Director;

listed document (表列文件) means—(a)a document listed in column 2 of the Table in Part 2 of Schedule 2 that is referred to in a provision listed in column 3 of that Table corresponding to the document; or(b)a document listed in column 2 of that Table the subject matter of which is referred to in a provision listed in column 3 of that Table corresponding to the document.

section.name: s55B
section.heading: Listed documents may be issued or granted electronically

subsection.content: A listed document that may be issued or granted by the Director under a provision of this Ordinance may be issued or granted by the Director in electronic form.
The Director must cause a listed document issued or granted by the Director in electronic form under subsection (1) to be kept in the e-document database.

section.name: s55C
section.heading: Listed documents may be cancelled or withdrawn electronically

subsection.content: A listed document that may be cancelled or withdrawn by the Director under a provision of this Ordinance may be cancelled or withdrawn by the Director in electronic form.
The Director must cause a cancellation or withdrawal made by the Director in electronic form under subsection (1) to be entered in the e-document database with respect to the listed document.

section.name: s55D
section.heading: Keeping and producing listed documents electronically by making them available for viewing from electronic device on board or at relevant place

subsection.leadIn: If the keeping, or production for inspection, of a listed document, or a copy of the document, on board the vessel, or at a relevant place, to which the document relates is required under a provision of this Ordinance, the requirement is also met—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: by making the document readily accessible for viewing from an electronic device—

subparagraph.content: if the provision requires the keeping, or production for inspection, of the document or copy on board the vessel—on board the vessel; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the device is not functioning properly—by producing a printout of the document in electronic form—

subparagraph.content: if the provision requires the keeping, or production for inspection, of the document or copy on board the vessel—on board the vessel; or
if the provision requires the keeping, or production for inspection, of the document or copy at the relevant place—at the relevant place.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)—
subsection.def: printout (打印本) includes a copy of a printout;
relevant place (相關地方), in relation to a listed document that is evidence of any permission granted by the Director for a person to do an act at a place, means the place.

section.name: s55E
section.heading: Power of Secretary for Transport and Logistics to amend Schedule 2

subsection.content: The Secretary for Transport and Logistics may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend Schedule 2.

A notice published under subsection (1) may contain any incidental, supplementary, consequential, savings or transitional provisions that are necessary or expedient in consequence of the amendments made under that subsection.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Power to declare ports
section.text: The Secretary for Transport and Logistics may, by order published in the Gazette, declare any area of the waters of Hong Kong to be a port.

section.name: s57
section.heading: Power of Chief Executive to give directions

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may give to the Director and to any public officer such directions as he thinks fit, either generally or in any particular case, with respect to the performance or exercise of their respective duties or powers under this Ordinance.
A person to whom a direction is given by the Chief Executive under subsection (1) shall, in the performance or exercise of his duties or powers under this Ordinance, comply with that direction.

Subject to subsection (3), the Director may, either generally or in any particular case, delegate to any other public officer the performance or exercise on his behalf of any of the functions, duties or powers imposed or conferred upon him under this Ordinance.

Where any function, duty or power imposed or conferred on the Director under this Ordinance is performed or exercised by any other public officer, the Director shall, unless the contrary is proved, be deemed to have delegated to the public officer under subsection (1) the performance or exercise of the function, duty or power.

subsection.leadIn: No delegation under subsection (1) shall be made of any power—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to amend a Schedule to the regulations made under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: under section 63, except in respect of a provision specified for the purposes of this section in Schedule 1; or (Replaced 46 of 1981 s. 9. Amended 24 of 2005 s. 43; 16 of 2024 s. 4)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to make exemptions under any regulation made under section 80(1)(i)(i), except in respect of a provision specified for the purposes of this section in Schedule 1. (Added 24 of 2005 s. 43. Amended 16 of 2024 s. 4)

subsection.content: The Chief Executive in Council may, by order published in the Gazette, amend Schedule 1. (Added 46 of 1981 s. 9. Amended 64 of 1999 s. 3; 16 of 2024 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to any other provision of this Ordinance, an authorized officer may, at any time of day or night, stop and board any vessel in the waters of Hong Kong, other than a warship, for the purpose of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: inspecting or searching the vessel or any part thereof;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: investigating any occurrence specified in section 67(1), whether or not such occurrence has been reported to the Director under that section;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: making such examination and investigation as may be necessary where any provision of this Ordinance or any other enactment has been contravened in respect of the vessel or by any person on board the vessel, or where an authorized officer has reasonable grounds for suspecting that such contravention has taken place;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: directing the conduct of any other authorized officer who may be on board the vessel;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: observing, inspecting or searching any person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for the time being on board the vessel;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: employed, engaged or dwelling on board the vessel; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: employed or engaged in loading or unloading the vessel; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: taking any action which he considers necessary—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to provide against fire or accident on board the vessel;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to preserve peace and good order on board the vessel; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: to prevent or detect any offence under this Ordinance or any other enactment in respect of the vessel or by any person on board the vessel.

subsection.leadIn: Any police officer of or above the rank of Sergeant may— (Amended 60 of 1979 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: take into custody and remove from any vessel in the waters of Hong Kong, other than a warship, any person who he suspects on reasonable grounds of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: having committed an offence under this Ordinance or any other enactment; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: having boarded, or remained on board, the vessel without the permission of the owner or his agent or of the master of the vessel. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

subsection.content: An authorized officer boarding a vessel under subsection (1) may take with him such persons as may be necessary to assist him for the purposes of this section.

The master of a vessel, when required to stop the vessel by an authorized officer in the exercise of his powers under subsection (1), shall stop the vessel and permit the authorized officer to board the vessel.

subsection.leadIn: Any master who without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to comply with a direction given under subsection (2)(b); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: contravenes subsection (4),

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), for the purpose of any investigation by an inspector under section 39 or by an authorized officer under section 59, an inspector or authorized officer may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: require that the vessel which he has boarded or any part of it, or anything therein, shall be left undisturbed (whether generally or in particular respects) for so long as is necessary to carry out the investigation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: take such measurements and photographs and make such recordings as he considers necessary;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inspect, seize and remove from the vessel any article or substance in respect of which he suspects on reasonable grounds that an offence under this Ordinance or any other enactment has been committed;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of any article or substance removed under paragraph (c), detain it for so long as is necessary—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to examine it and to cause it to be subjected to any process or test;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to ensure that it is not tampered with before the examination of it is completed;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: to ensure that it is available for use as evidence in any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance or any other enactment;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: require any person whom he has reasonable cause to believe to be able to give any information relevant to the investigation to answer (in the absence of persons other than a person nominated by him to be present and any persons whom the inspector or authorized officer may allow to be present) such questions as the inspector or authorized officer thinks fit to ask and to sign a declaration of the truth of his answers;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: require the production of, inspect, and take copies of any entry in, the log book of the vessel or any document which it is necessary for him to see for the purposes of the investigation.

subsection.content: No answer given by a person in pursuance of a requirement imposed under subsection (1)(e) shall be admissible in evidence against that person or the husband or wife of that person in any proceedings.
For the purpose of an investigation under section 39, the powers of an inspector shall be limited to matters to which Part V relates or to offences under that Part.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contravenes any requirement imposed by an inspector or authorized officer under subsection (1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prevents any other person from appearing before an inspector or authorized officer or from answering any question to which an inspector or authorized officer may by virtue of subsection (1)(e) require an answer,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 3 of 2021)

section.name: s60A
section.heading: Powers of authorized officers to enter premises, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to this section, an authorized officer may, on producing, if so required, some duly authenticated document showing his authority, enter any non-domestic premises at any time between the hours of 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. for the purposes of—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: taking any action authorized or required to be taken by or under this Ordinance in respect of any such vessel found on the premises.

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate may, if satisfied by information on oath that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: admission to any non-domestic premises has been refused or that refusal is apprehended, or that such premises are unoccupied, or that the occupier is temporarily absent, or that the case is one of urgency, or that an application for admission would defeat the object of the entry, or that it is reasonable for the purposes of this Ordinance in the circumstances of the case that entry be effected between the hours of 7 p.m. and 7 a.m.; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is reasonable ground for entry into the premises for any of the purposes of subsection (1),

subsection.continued: issue a warrant authorizing an authorized officer to effect entry, if need be by force:
subsection.proviso: Provided that such warrant shall not be issued unless the magistrate is satisfied that notice of the intention to apply for a warrant has been given to the occupier of the premises, or that the premises are unoccupied, or that the occupier is temporarily absent, or that the case is one of urgency, or that the giving of such notice would defeat the object of the entry, or that it is reasonable for the purposes of this Ordinance in the circumstances of the case that entry be effected between the hours of 7 p.m. and 7 a.m., as may be appropriate.

content.leadIn: A magistrate may, if satisfied by information on oath that there is reasonable ground for entry into domestic premises for any of the purposes of subsection (1), issue a warrant authorizing an authorized officer to effect entry between the hours of 7 a.m. and 7 p.m., if need be by force:
content.proviso: Provided that such warrant shall not be issued unless the magistrate is satisfied that notice of the intention to apply for a warrant has been given to the occupier of the premises, or that the premises are unoccupied, or that the occupier is temporarily absent, or that the case is one of urgency, or that the giving of such notice would defeat the object of the entry.

subsection.content: Any authorized officer entering any premises by virtue of the provisions of subsection (1) or of a warrant issued under subsection (2) or (3) may take with him such persons as may be necessary, and on leaving any unoccupied premises which he has so entered, shall leave such premises as effectually secured against trespassers as he found the same to be at the time of entry.
Every warrant issued under subsection (2) or (3) shall continue in force until the purpose for which the entry is necessary has been satisfied.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section—
subsection.def: domestic premises (住宅處所) means any premises used wholly or mainly for residential purposes and constituting a separate household unit; and
non-domestic premises (非住宅處所) means any premises other than domestic premises.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a vessel is involved in any occurrence specified in section 67(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the master, person in charge or person in control of a vessel is suspected of having committed an offence under this Ordinance involving the use of the vessel,
